attributes.comment:
We are writing to you and your department both as US citizens and parents-to-be
of a child from China regarding current USCIS regulations that affect the
process and cost of China adoption. This letter contains a little bit about us
and a proposal for changing the current system.

Our dream of completing a family has been, and continues to be, a ?long and
winding road?. To fulfill our dream we chose China. At times we have found the
process to be both difficult and confronting. We have had to submit to the
scrutiny of our adoption agency, our state, our federal government, and the
Chinese government. When we gave birth to our first child, we did not have a
social worker come to our house to ask us questions about our childhood, our
marriage, and our parenting ideas. We did not have to provide everyone with
proof that we were not criminals, and that we had not ever abused, neglected or
abandoned a child. We did not have to prove that we were physically and
financially healthy and stable. But, this is only a part of what it takes if you
want to parent a child from China! The investment of our time, money and
emotions has been substantial. We have followed all the rules of both the United
States and the Peoples Republic of China. We filled out the dozens of required
forms, ordered the required documents, prepared our dossier and immigration
files and sent them to China. Finally, after all this, we have allowed ourselves
to be filled with the myriad of hopes, fears, dreams and desires of all waiting
parents!

As part of this process we are required to obtain USCIS approval (form
I-171H/I-797C). We originally applied for the I171-H in the Fall of 2005. Only
after our home study was completed were we given an appointment for
fingerprinting that was more than a month out. Nearly 2 months after
fingerprinting we received our valid I171-H on March 24 of 2006. According to
current regulations it is valid for 18 months (September 2007). Until recently,
this approval period served families in the process of China adoption quite
well. They were able to receive their child referral, travel to China, receive
their child and submit an I-600 in Guangzhou for their child?s visa. This is
what we had been looking forward to for our family, our adoption journey.
Unfortunately, China is now experiencing a significant increase in the length of
time it will take to match us with our child.

This increased waiting timeline has occurred quickly and with dramatic effects.
It is a certainty that every family who has a dossier in China will experience
the expiration of their: 1) fingerprints (valid for 15 months) and I-171H/I-797C
approval (valid for 18 months). The cost, both emotionally and financially of
filing a new I-600A will be very high. The cost to your USCIS offices for
processing a new I-600A will be very costly and time consuming. House Resolution
628 is before the Judiciary Committe to extend the I-171H. However, if the bill
does not pass, the addition burden imposed by the higher fees will negatively
affect our family as well as thousands of others. In addition to the cost of a
new I-171H, we will have to pay $145 more that it would have this year. Since
the USCIS does not directly control the length of time the I171H is valid,
please help by controlling the cost of reapplication. I would propose a reduced
rate for those who've already applied and received a valid I171H. Given that it
took several months to receive the I171-H in the first place, we believe that
another $670 reapplication fee is simply disproportionate and excessive.
Increasing the cost on us now adds to the pain.


Thank you for your time and thoughtfulness about this matter.
Sincerely,
Timothy & Scarlet Thomas
Spartan_tim@yahoo.com
Scarlet_thomas@yahoo.com

Comment on FR Doc # E7-01631
